description:
Amborella trichopoda is a small, evergreen shrub or small tree native to the tropical rainforests of New Caledonia, a French overseas territory in the South Pacific Ocean. It is the sole extant member of the plant family Amborellaceae and is considered one of the most basal and earliest-diverging lineages of flowering plants (angiosperms).

Amborella trichopoda is a dioecious species, meaning that individual plants are either male or female. The leaves are simple, oblong, and leathery, with a distinctive tripartite venation pattern. The flowers are small, inconspicuous, and lack petals, with both male and female structures present within a single flower.

Amborella trichopoda is of great scientific interest due to its phylogenetic position as one of the earliest-diverging angiosperms. Its unique characteristics, such as the tripartite venation and the presence of specific reproductive features, have provided valuable insights into the evolutionary origins and early diversification of flowering plants, which are the dominant plants in most terrestrial ecosystems today.

The conservation status of Amborella trichopoda is considered vulnerable due to its limited distribution and threats from habitat loss and degradation. Efforts are ongoing to protect this species and its unique ecosystem in New Caledonia.
